## Claude Code with Astro

Claude Code is being used alongside AstroJS for static site generation, with developers using it to help transform content and manage workflows.

Claude Code is an agentic coding tool that runs on the command line, and enabling the Astro Docs MCP server allows it to access the latest documentation while generating Astro code.

## SSR Design Considerations in Astro

### Key SSR Concepts

A chat application built with Astro features "Server-Side Rendering: Fast initial page loads with SSR support" as one of its core features.

Astro has one key advantage: it was designed to run on the server, allowing you to write server code free from unnecessary abstractions that come with other "universal" SPA-first frameworks.

### SSR Requirements

To build for server-side rendering, the Astro build command must know what server you'll eventually be deploying to, as SSR requires a server runtime that renders Astro pages, which Astro provides through adapters.

Available Astro adapters include Cloudflare, Deno, Netlify, NodeJS and Vercel.

### Response Handling

Features that modify Response headers are only available at the page level and cannot be used inside components; by the time Astro runs component code, Response headers have been sent and cannot be modified.

### Best Practices for Claude Code with Astro

One developer started with a blank Astro application, created a claude.md file with thorough instructions including strict TypeScript typing and always using the "Astro way" according to documentation.

## Automated Code Review Implementation

You can automate code reviews with Claude Code using an AI code-review agent system. The workflow transforms traditional reviews:

**Traditional approach:** Humans handled everything including style nits, security checks, acceptance criteria, UX sanity, and architecture, often missing things under load like spec drift and auth gaps.

**AI-assisted approach:** The AI agent handles blocking and tackling first (security scanning, style/arch conformance, test adequacy, spec checks) while humans review acceptance and strategy.

- The code-reviewer subagent is described as an expert code review specialist
- Production-ready Claude subagents collections include 100+ specialized AI agents for various development tasks

Here's a comprehensive overview of slash commands in Claude Code:

Slash Commands Overview
----------------------

### Built-in Commands
Claude Code includes several pre-defined slash commands like:
- `/add-dir`: Add working directories
- `/agents`: Manage AI subagents
- `/clear`: Clear conversation history
- `/help`: Get usage help
- `/init`: Initialize project
- `/model`: Select AI model

### Custom Slash Commands

#### Creation Locations
1. Project-level commands: `.claude/commands/`
2. Personal commands: `~/.claude/commands/`

#### Command Syntax
```
/<command-name> [arguments]
```

#### Argument Handling
- `$ARGUMENTS`: Captures all arguments
- `$1`, `$2`, etc.: Access specific arguments

#### Frontmatter Options
```yaml
---
allowed-tools: Bash(git add:*)
argument-hint: [message]
description: Create a git commit
model: claude-3-5-haiku-20241022
disable-model-invocation: false
---
```

#### Example Custom Command
```markdown
# .claude/commands/optimize.md
---
description: Analyze code for performance issues
argument-hint: [file-path]
---
Analyze @$1 for performance optimization opportunities.
```

#### Advanced Features
- Bash command execution with `!` prefix
- File references with `@` prefix
- Thinking mode triggers
- Namespacing through subdirectories

### MCP Slash Commands
- Dynamically discovered from connected servers
- Format: `/mcp__<server-name>__<prompt-name>`

### SlashCommand Tool
- Allows programmatic command execution
- Requires description in frontmatter
- Character budget limit (default 15,000 characters)

Here's a comprehensive overview of subagents based on the Claude Docs page:

Subagents Overview
-----------------

### Definition
Subagents are specialized AI assistants with:
- A specific purpose and expertise area
- A separate context window
- Configurable tools
- Custom system prompts

### Key Benefits
- Preserve main conversation context
- Provide specialized expertise
- Enable reusable workflows
- Allow flexible tool permissions

### File Structure
Subagents are stored as Markdown files with YAML frontmatter in two locations:
1. Project-level: `.claude/agents/` (Highest priority)
2. User-level: `~/.claude/agents/`

### YAML Frontmatter Configuration

Required Fields:
- `name`: Unique identifier (lowercase, hyphen-separated)
- `description`: Purpose of the subagent

Optional Fields:
- `tools`: Specific tools to grant access
- `model`: Model selection (`sonnet`, `opus`, `haiku`, or `inherit`)

### Example Subagent Configuration

```yaml
---
name: code-reviewer
description: Expert code review specialist
tools: Read, Grep, Glob, Bash
model: inherit
---

# Detailed system prompt goes here
You are a senior code reviewer ensuring high standards...
```

### Best Practices
- Create focused, single-purpose subagents
- Write detailed system prompts
- Limit tool access
- Version control project subagents

### Invocation Methods
1. Automatic delegation
2. Explicit invocation: `> Use the code-reviewer subagent to check my recent changes`

### Example Subagents Provided
- Code Reviewer
- Debugger
- Data Scientist

### Management
- Use `/agents` command for interactive management
- Manually edit Markdown files in `.claude/agents/`

## Claude Code with Playwright MCP Setup

You can use the official microsoft/playwright-mcp Playwright MCP server with Claude Code. The setup process is straightforward:

### Installation

When you run claude, Playwright will be available after adding the MCP server using Claude Code's built-in command. The claude mcp add command will persist but will only affect the directory in which you run it.

### Configuration Details

Configuration is tracked in a JSON file ~/.claude.json which includes a "projects" key with objects for each directory used with Claude Code in the past, including MCPs and allowed commands.

### Using Playwright MCP

You can say things like: Use playwright mcp to open a browser to example.com, and a visible Chrome browser window, controlled by Claude Code, will open. You may need to explicitly say "playwright mcp" the first time, otherwise it might try to use Bash to run Playwright instead.

Since Claude uses a visible browser window when interacting with Playwright, authentication is easy: have it show you a login page, then login yourself with your own credentials and tell it what to do next, with cookies persisting for the duration of the session.

### Available Tools

With the MCP loaded you can run /mcp and then navigate to playwright to view all available tools.

### Alternative MCP Servers

There's also an ExecuteAutomation MCP server that provides browser automation capabilities using Playwright, enabling LLMs to interact with web pages, take screenshots, generate test code, web scrape pages and execute JavaScript in a real browser environment.

A claude.md file is a special Markdown file that Claude Code automatically ingests to gain project-specific context before it starts working.(no content)The workflow can be optimized by using `CLAUDE.md` files for context, curating allowed tools, and using bash tools and MCP.

### What to Include in CLAUDE.md

A well-structured claude.md file should contain: Tech Stack: A declaration of your project's tools and versions (e.g., Astro 4.5, Tailwind CSS 3.4, TypeScript 5.3).

The file should also include:
- Project Structure: An outline of key directories and their roles (e.g., src/components for reusable UI elements, src/lib for core business logic). Commands: A list of the most important npm, bash, or other scripts for building, testing, linting, and deploying your project.
- Code Style & Conventions: Explicit guidelines on formatting, naming conventions, import/export syntax, and other stylistic rules.
- Repository Etiquette: Instructions on branch naming (feature/TICKET-123-description), commit message formats, and whether to merge or rebase.

### Writing Style Best Practices

"You're writing for Claude, not onboarding a junior dev."

Key guidelines:
- Use short, declarative bullet points. Don't: Write long, narrative paragraphs. Do: Trim redundancy.
- Use standard Markdown headings (#, ##) to organize your file into logical sections. A clear structure helps both you and the AI quickly parse the information.

### Important Considerations

The contents of your claude.md are prepended to your prompts, consuming part of your token budget with every interaction. A bloated, verbose file will not only cost more but can also introduce noise that makes it harder for the model to follow the important instructions.

### Workflow Tips

During a session, you can press # to give Claude an instruction that it will automatically incorporate into the relevant claude.md file. This lets you build out your context file organically as you work.

Be specific when working with Claude Code - tell the agent exactly what to do and how to do it, as the more specific you are, the better the results will be.

Composables should only be called in <script setup> or the setup() hook, and they should be called synchronously in these contexts.

Remember to clean up side effects in onUnmounted() - for example, if a composable sets up a DOM event listener, it should remove that listener in onUnmounted().
